qas.question: Who referred St. John's as St. "the principal prime and chief lot in all the whole country" ?
When did censuses start being conducted in St. John's?
When did Irish men begin to operate inshore fishing boats in St. John's?
What grew during the summers in St. John's?
Who controlled most of Newfoundland's east coast by 1620?

plausible_answers.text: the fishermen of England's West Country

qas.question: Who controlled the east coast of Newfoundland in the 16th century?

plausible_answers.text: "the principal prime and chief lot in all the whole country"

qas.question: What did William Payne call St. Johns in the 16th century?
Who started taking censuses in the 16th century?
What caused the population to decrease in the summer?

context: By 1620, <b5_0>the <a4_0>fishermen<a4_0/> of England's West Country<b5_0/> controlled most of Newfoundland's east coast. In 1627, <a0_0>William Payne<a0_0/>, called St. John's <b6_0>"the principal prime and chief lot in all the whole country"<b6_0/>. <b7_0>The population<b7_0/> grew slowly in the 17th century and St. John's was the largest settlement in Newfoundland when <b8_0>English naval officers<b8_0/> began to take censuses around <a1_0>1675<a1_0/>. The <a3_0>population<a3_0/> would grow in the summers with the arrival of <b9_0>migratory fishermen<b9_0/>. In <a2_0>1680<a2_0/>, fishing ships (mostly from South Devon) set up fishing rooms at St. John's, bringing hundreds of Irish men into the port to operate inshore fishing boats.
